name: boot
content:
boot

noun
 
 
/buːt/
 
/buːt/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     
     a strong shoe that covers the foot and ankle and often the lower part of the leg
    • (British English) walking boots
    • a pair of heavy walking boots
    • (North American English) hiking boots
    • a pair of black leather boots
    • She wore black knee-high boots.
    see also cowboy boot, desert boot, football boot, wellingtonTopics Clothes and Fashiona1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • heavy
    • light
    • lightweight
    • …
    … of boots
    • pair
    verb + boot
    • have on
    • wear
    • put on
    • …
    boot + noun
    • polish
    phrases
    • as tough as old boots
    • the toe of somebody’s boot
    See full entry
  2. enlarge image
    (British English)
    (North American English trunk)
    the space at the back of a car that you put bags, cases, etc. in
    • I'll put the luggage in the boot.
    • Did you lock the boot?
    • What have you got in the boot?
    see also car boot sale
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • car
    verb + boot
    • open
    • close
    • shut
    • …
    preposition
    • in the boot
    See full entry
  3. [usually singular] (informal) a quick hard kick
    • He gave the ball a tremendous boot.
  4. (also Denver boot (both North American English), British English clamp, wheel clamp)
     a device that is attached to the wheel of a car that has been parked illegally, so that it cannot be driven away
    5. Word Originnoun Middle English: from Old Norse bóti or its source, Old French bote, of unknown ultimate origin. to boot. Old English bōt ‘advantage, remedy’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch boete and German Busse ‘penance, fine’, also to better and best.
Idioms
be given the boot | get the boot
  1. (informal) to be told that you must leave your job or that a relationship you are having with somebody is over
    • He should have been given the boot years ago.
be/get too big for your boots
(North American English also be/get too big for your britches)
  1. to be/become too proud of yourself; to behave as if you are more important than you really areTopics Personal qualitiesc2
the boot is on the other foot (British English)
(North American English the shoe is on the other foot)
  1. used to say that a situation has changed so that somebody now has power or authority over the person who used to have power or authority over them
fill your boots (informal)
  1. used to invite somebody to take as much as they like of something such as food, drink, etc; help yourself
fill somebody’s shoes/boots
  1. to do somebody’s job in an acceptable way when they are not there
lick somebody’s boots
(British English, taboo, slang lick somebody’s arse)
  1. (disapproving) to show too much respect for somebody in authority because you want to please them synonym crawl
put/stick the boot in (British English, informal)
  1. to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
  2. to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation
    • I wonder if the press will put the boot in?
shake in your boots/shoes
  1. (informal) to be very frightened or nervousTopics Feelingsc2
to boot
  1. (old-fashioned or humorous) used to add a comment to something that you have said
    • He was a vegetarian, and a fussy one to boot.
(as) tough as old boots | (as) tough as nails (informal)
  1. very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations
    • She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.
    Similes in idioms
See boot in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: boot

name: boot
content:
boot

verb
 
/buːt/
 
/buːt/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they boot
 
/buːt/
 
/buːt/
he / she / it boots
 
/buːts/
 
/buːts/
past simple booted
 
/ˈbuːtɪd/
 
/ˈbuːtɪd/
past participle booted
 
/ˈbuːtɪd/
 
/ˈbuːtɪd/
-ing form booting
 
/ˈbuːtɪŋ/
 
/ˈbuːtɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1. [transitive] boot something + adv./prep. to kick somebody/something hard with your foot
    • He booted the ball clear of the goal.
  2. [intransitive, transitive] boot (something) (up) (computing) to prepare a computer for use by loading its operating system; to be prepared in this wayTopics Computersc2
  3. [transitive]
    be/get booted
    (North American English, informal) if you or your car is booted, a piece of equipment is fixed to the car’s wheel so that you cannot drive it away, usually because the car is illegally parked see also clamp
    4. Word Originverb Middle English: from Old Norse bóti or its source, Old French bote, of unknown ultimate origin.
Phrasal Verbs
  • boot out
See boot in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: boot

name: clamp
content:
clamp

noun
 
/klæmp/
 
/klæmp/
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     a tool for holding things tightly together, usually by means of a screw
  2. (also wheel clamp)
     (both British English)
    (US English Denver boot, boot)
    a device that is attached to the wheel of a car that has been parked illegally, so that it cannot be driven awayTopics Transport by car or lorryc2
    3. Word OriginMiddle English: probably of Dutch or Low German origin and related to clam.
See clamp in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: clamp

name: boot-cut
content:
boot-cut

adjective
 
/ˈbuːt kʌt/
 
/ˈbuːt kʌt/
[usually before noun]
jump to other results
  1. boot-cut trousers are slightly wider at the bottom of the legs where the material goes over the feet or shoes
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryBoot-cut is used with these nouns:
    • jeans
    See full entry
See boot-cut in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: boot-cut

name: boot out
content:
boot out

phrasal verb
jump to other results
boot somebody out (of something)
  1. (informal) to force somebody to leave a place or job synonym throw out
See boot out in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: boot camp
content:
boot camp

noun
 
/ˈbuːt kæmp/
 
/ˈbuːt kæmp/
jump to other results
  1. a training camp for new members of the armed forces, where they have to work hard
    • He had recently graduated from Marine Corps boot camp.
  2. a type of prison for young criminals where there is strict disciplineTopics Crime and punishmentc2
  3. a short course of very hard physical training
    • I joined a boot camp to get fit.
    • (figurative) You can cram for the exam at a one-week boot camp.
See boot camp in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: boot camp

name: Boot Hill
content:
Boot Hill

noun
 
/ˌbuːt ˈhɪl/
 
/ˌbuːt ˈhɪl/
[uncountable] (US English, informal, humorous)
jump to other results
  1. (in the Wild West) a place where people are buried
    CultureOne of the best known is at Tombstone, Arizona. The name comes from the idea that many people were buried in the boots they were wearing when they were killed.
See Boot Hill in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Boot Hill

name: boot sale
content:
boot sale

noun
 
/ˈbuːt seɪl/
 
/ˈbuːt seɪl/
(also car boot sale, car boot)
(British English)
jump to other results
  1. an outdoor sale where people sell things that they no longer want, using tables or the backs of their cars to put the goods on
Check pronunciation: boot sale

name: boot-faced
content:
boot-faced

adjective
 
/ˌbuːt ˈfeɪst/
 
/ˌbuːt ˈfeɪst/
(British English, informal)
jump to other results
  1. looking very serious, angry or annoyed
    • The boot-faced security guard wouldn’t let us in.
Check pronunciation: boot-faced

name: cowboy boot
content:
cowboy boot

noun
 
/ˈkaʊbɔɪ buːt/
 
/ˈkaʊbɔɪ buːt/
jump to other results
  1. a type of leather boot with a high heel and a pointed toe, originally worn by cowboys
    • Gemma wore a pair of white cowboy boots decorated with silver stitching.
    Topics Clothes and Fashionc1
